segment.source: This article explains how to add fingerprint biometrics to your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article explains how to add fingerprint biometrics to your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: This article explains how to add fingerprint biometrics to your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article explains how to add fingerprint biometrics to your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Including a request for fingerprint authentication when the user must consent to a particular action increases the security of your app.
segment.target: Including a request for fingerprint authentication when the user must consent to a particular action increases the security of your app.

segment.source: For example, you could require fingerprint authentication before authorizing an in-app purchase, or access to restricted resources.
segment.target: For example, you could require fingerprint authentication before authorizing an in-app purchase, or access to restricted resources.

segment.source: Fingerprint authentication is managed using the UserConsentVerifier class in the Windows.Security.Credentials.UI namespace.
segment.target: Fingerprint authentication is managed using the UserConsentVerifier class in the Windows.Security.Credentials.UI namespace.

segment.source: Check the device for a fingerprint reader
segment.target: Check the device for a fingerprint reader

segment.source: To find out whether the device has a fingerprint reader, call UserConsentVerifier.CheckAvailabilityAsync.
segment.target: To find out whether the device has a fingerprint reader, call UserConsentVerifier.CheckAvailabilityAsync.

segment.source: Even if a device supports fingerprint authentication, your app should still provide users with an option in Settings to enable or disable it.
segment.target: Even if a device supports fingerprint authentication, your app should still provide users with an option in Settings to enable or disable it.

segment.source: To request user consent from a fingerprint scan, call the UserConsentVerifier.RequestVerificationAsync method.
segment.target: To request user consent from a fingerprint scan, call the UserConsentVerifier.RequestVerificationAsync method.

segment.source: For fingerprint authentication to work, the user must have previously added a fingerprint "signature" to the fingerprint database.
segment.target: For fingerprint authentication to work, the user must have previously added a fingerprint "signature" to the fingerprint database.

segment.source: When you call the UserConsentVerifier.RequestVerificationAsync, the user is presented with a modal dialog requesting a fingerprint scan.
segment.target: When you call the UserConsentVerifier.RequestVerificationAsync, the user is presented with a modal dialog requesting a fingerprint scan.

segment.source: You can supply a message to the UserConsentVerifier.RequestVerificationAsync method that will be displayed to the user as part of the modal dialog, as shown in the following image.
segment.target: You can supply a message to the UserConsentVerifier.RequestVerificationAsync method that will be displayed to the user as part of the modal dialog, as shown in the following image.
